ImageItem.internal_link_text: Select BizTalk Service and select Custom Create
Select BizTalk Service and select Custom Create

td.caps_html_text_node: You can enter any name but be specific. Some examples include:
.biztalk.windows.net
.biztalk.windows.net
.biztalk.windows.net
".biztalk.windows.net" is automatically added to the name you enter. This creates a URL that is used to access your BizTalk Service, like
If you are in the testing/development phase, choose
. If you are in the production phase, use the
to determine if
, or
is the correct choice for your business scenario.

tr.td: Select the geographic region to host your BizTalk Service.

td.caps_html_text_node: . By default, the domain URL is
.biztalk.windows.net. A custom domain can also be entered. For example, if your domain is
, you can enter:
.contoso.com
.contoso.com
.contoso.com
.contoso.com
Select an existing storage account or create a new storage account.
If you create a new Storage account, enter the
If you use an existing Azure SQL Database, it cannot be used by another BizTalk Service. You need the login name and password entered when that Azure SQL Database Server was created.
Create the Tracking database and Monitoring/Archiving storage account in the same region as the BizTalk Service.
Available when
td.strong: Create a new SQL Database instance
td.caps_html_text_node: is selected in the previous screen.
Enter a SQL Database name to be used by your BizTalk Service.
Available when
td.strong: Create a new SQL Database instance
td.caps_html_text_node: is selected in the previous screen.
Select an existing SQL Database Server or create a new SQL Database server.
Available when
td.strong: Create a new SQL Database instance
td.caps_html_text_node: is selected. Select the geographic region to host your SQL Database.

LinkItem.internal_link_text: Install the certificate on a local computer
Install the certificate on a local computer

ImageItem.internal_link_text: ACS Service Identities in the Access Control Management Portal
ACS Service Identities in the Access Control Management Portal

td.caps_html_text_node: The subscription determines who can sign in to the Azure portal. The Account holder creates the subscription at
The Azure account can have multiple subscriptions and can be managed by anyone who is permitted. For example, your Azure account holder creates a subscription named

and gives the BizTalk Administrators within your company (for example, ContosoBTSAdmins@live.com) access to this subscription. In this scenario, the BizTalk Administrators sign in to the Azure portal and have full Administrator rights to all the hosted services in the subscription, including Azure BizTalk Services. The BizTalk Administrators are not the Azure account holders and therefore don't have access to any billing information.
td.a: Manage Subscriptions and Storage Accounts in the Azure portal
td.caps_html_text_node: provides more information.
Stores the tables, views, and stored procedures used by the BizTalk Service, including the Tracking data.
When you create a BizTalk Service, you can use an existing Azure SQL Server, Azure SQL Database, or automatically create a new Server or Database.
The SQL Database scale is automatically configured. Typically, the default scale is sufficient for a BizTalk Service. Changing the scale impacts pricing. See
td.a: Accounts and Billing in Azure SQL Database

ul.li: When you create a new Azure SQL Server and Database, Azure Services is automatically enabled. The BizTalk Service requires Azure Services be enabled.

If you create a new Azure SQL Database on an existing Azure SQL Server, the firewall rules of the Server are not changed. As a result, it's possible other Azure Services are not allowed access to the Server's databases.

tr.td: Authenticates with Azure BizTalk Services. When you deploy a BizTalk Service project from Visual Studio, you enter this Access Control namespace. When you create a BizTalk Service, the Access Control namespace is automatically created.

td.caps_html_text_node: Gives access to tables, blobs, and queues used by your BizTalk Service to save the following:

ul.li: Log files that monitor the BizTalk Service. The monitoring output is also displayed in the **Monitoring** tab in the Azure portal.
When creating an X12 or AS2 agreement between partners, you can enable the Archiving feature to store message properties. This data is saved in the Storage account.

td.caps_html_text_node: When you create a BizTalk Service, you can use an existing Storage account or automatically create a new Storage account.
The default Storage settings are sufficient for a BizTalk Service.

When you create a Storage account, a Primary Key and Secondary Key are automatically created. These Keys control access to your Storage account. The BizTalk Service automatically uses the Primary Key.
See
for more information.

When an Azure BizTalk Service is created, an HTTPS URL that includes your BizTalk Service name is also created. This URL is automatically configured to use a self-signed development-only certificate. For production, you need a private SSL certificate.

ul.li: The certificate expiration date must be less than 5 years.
All private certificates require a password. Know this password and as a best practice, share this password with your administrators.

Self-signed certificates are used in a test/development environment. When using self-signed certificates, import the certificate to your Personal certificate store and the Trusted Root Certification Authorities certificate store.

td.caps_html_text_node: When sending the production certificate request to your certification authority, give the following certificate properties:

li.caps_html_text_node: : At a minimum, Azure BizTalk Services requires Server Authentication.
: Enter the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of your Azure BizTalk Service URL. See

td.caps_html_text_node: A new or different certificate can be added after the BizTalk Service is created.
